data.title: Debian Squeeze Build non-working binary
data.body:
Building atom on Debian squeeze makes a binary, but when I open it I receive a message saying
`An javascript error occured in the browser`

Atom does not open after dismissing the error.

data.title: Add cut/copy/paste built-in context menu items
data.body:
Closes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1638

This change allows built-in context menu commands to be defined in Atom's menu config files (096255f) and adds the core copy/cut/paste commands to the context menu (776a8e9).

The built-in context menu commands are defined in the same way as they are in packages -- there's a `context-menu` key, and commands scoped to a selector. 

Here's the menu in action:

![copy](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/4059313/487fc4fe-2de3-11e4-8a47-699219c332ab.gif)

cc @kevinsawicki for :eyes:

data.title: Mac OS - Unable to open large directory structures
data.body:
Hi,

I updated my install to 0.124.0 this morning and I'm now unable to open ( cmd-o | file - open ) the project that I've been using inside of Atom for several months.

OS: 10.9.4

The Title of panel changes to the root directory of the structure I want to load but nothing else happens.

The directory structure is quite large:  (3.17 GB on disk) for 40,235 items but it's been working fine until the most recent build.

data.title: Ubuntu  - window class
data.body:
I am getting this warning in the cairo-dock on ubuntu 14.04 whenever I open atom:

this window (untitled, 85983233) doesn't belong to any class, skip it.
Please report this bug to the application's devs.

Is there a way to have this fixed?

data.title: No setting for replacing the current selection with quotes.
data.body:
There should be a setting that allows for the replacement of the current selection rather than wrapping it with quotes when you type a quote.
##### Repro:
1. Type `this is a selection`
2. Highlight the words `this is a selection`
3. Type `'`
##### Result:
1. The editor displays the text `'this is a selection'`
##### Expected when allowing automatic quote wrapping:
1. The editor displays the text `'this is a selection'`
##### Expected when disabling automatic quote wrapping:
1. The editor displays the text `'`
##### Note:
1. This probably should just be a matter of disabling some default keybinding, however, there does not appear to be a keybinding set for `'` or `"`.

data.title: Update to atom-shell@0.15 breaks atom for linux users
data.body:
**Note**: This issue stems from a support issue: https://discuss.atom.io/t/cannot-run-atom-on-ubuntu-built-from-source/11611/10

On Ubuntu linux (it appears to only be some variants), the current master/HEAD of atom results in:
LaunchProcess: failed to execvp:
/proc/self/exe
[14050:0819/192435:ERROR:child_process_launcher.cc(329)] Failed to launch child process

When running `atom -f` on the command line. The atom editor itself never launches, but it appears to still be running in the background.

I've bisected this to the following revision:

```
3274ef9fb92766cfd998035b834ef5c562183315 is the first bad commit
commit 3274ef9fb92766cfd998035b834ef5c562183315
Author: Cheng Zhao <zcbenz@gmail.com>
Date:   Tue Jul 29 14:27:32 2014 +0800

    Upgrade to atom-shell@0.15.0

:100644 100644 3edf94dc4fc5a21edc943d426d628e34d4a709c5 e4cd0d840374a0e7e46bc86858dc1a865996dbf5 M  package.json
```

This appears to only happen on some versions of ubuntu linux (mine is 12.10). I don't exactly know how to include an existing atom-shell into a build of atom, so I don't know how to bisect atom-shell for more information.

I imagine window position is cached somewhere for each instance of Atom I've previously run. I don't see anything different in the default CSS here versus when I have any other files or folders opened.

data.title: Use RxJS observables in workspace API
data.body:
## Abstract

We have many situations where we need to subscribe to streams of events, such as discrete events like `did-insert-text`, properties with values that change over time, and collections with contents that change over time. The concept of _observables_ unifies all these callback-oriented patterns in a single compositional framework. The [RxJS](https://github.com/Reactive-Extensions/RxJS) library provides a mature and full-featured implementation of the observables concept, and I'd like to try using it in workspace. If it works well, we can consider using it for our events across the board.
## Tasks
- [ ] Benchmark to make sure overhead is acceptable in simple use cases
- [ ] :wrench: Replace workspace events with `::onX` methods that return observables
- [ ] :wrench: Replace workspace behaviors with `::observeX` that return observables
- [ ] Replace workspace `::eachX` methods with `::observeX` methods
## Description
### Events

We currently implement events via emissary's `Emitter` mixin. In the following example, we use `::on` to subscribe to all changes and `::once` to subscribe to the next change. Both methods return subscriptions which can be disposed with

``` coffee
subscription = editor.on 'text-did-change', -> # ...
subscription = editor.once 'text-did-change', -> # ...
```

Subscribing to events with strings is fragile and difficult to document, shim, and deprecate. We've discussed changing the API to use methods instead, such as `::onTextDidChange`, but there were concerns about losing `::once`. Returning an Rx observable gives us the ability to use `::once` semantics and also ton more.

Our `::on*` methods can be overloaded, so they subscribe if passed a callback and return an observable if no callback is passed.

``` coffee
# If a callback is passed, subscribe as normal
subscription = editor.onTextDidChange -> # ...

# If no callback is passed, return an observable
observable = editor.onTextDidChange()

# You can subscribe to observables
subscription = observable.subscribe -> # ...

# But you can also apply operators, such as `::take`.
# This is equivalent to `::once` from the example above.
subscription = observable.take(1).subscribe -> # ...

# You can also apply other operators, such as `::throttle`
# Here we will not handle text changes more often than once per 500ms
subscription = editor.onTextDidChange().throttle(500).subscribe -> # ...
```
### Properties That Change

In addition to events, we also need to track values that change over time. Observables are a great tool for this as well, and could replace `emissary` behaviors. For any model property `foo`, we could have an `observeFoo` method along with `getFoo` and `setFoo`. This would return an observable based on the current value of the property. Whenever someone subscribed, the `onNext` callback would be called immediately with the current value, then again whenever the value changed.

``` coffee
# Just like with `::on*` methods, `::observe*` can be passed a callback.
subscription = pane.observeActiveItem -> # ...

# Observe methods return an observable when called without a callback.
observable = pane.observeActiveItem()
subscription = observable.subscribe -> # ...

# If you only want changes and not the current value, skip it
# This is similar to passing `callNow: false` to config.observe,
# and could replace it
subscription = pane.observeActiveItem().skip(1).subscribe(@onActiveItemChanged)
```

Compositional operators can also be used to derive more advanced behaviors, such as `PaneContainer::observeActivePaneItem`, which will be based on the active item of the active pane.

``` coffee
class Workspace
  observeActivePaneItem: ->
    @observeActivePane().selectSwitch (activePane) ->
      activePane.observeActiveItem()
```
### Collections That Change

In addition to properties that change, we also deal with collections that change, such as the current panes, pane items, text editors, etc. These can also be modeled as observables. In the following example, `::observePanes` returns an observable that yields every current and future pane to observers.

``` coffee
# Can be called with a callback to subscribe immediately
subscription = atom.workspace.observePanes -> # ...

# When called without a callback, returns an observable
subscription = atom.workspace.observePanes().subscribe -> # ...
```

Again, the compositional nature of observables allows us to easily build derived collections, such as a collection based on all pane items.

``` coffee
class Workspace
  observePaneItems: ->
    @observePanes().flatMap (pane) -> pane.observeItems()
```

Such a method could filter on optional type selectors, allowing you to observe only a certain subset of panes.

``` coffee
class Workspace
  observeTextEditors: ->
    @observePaneItems('.text, .source')

  # The filter step would probably go in Pane::observeItems, but this
  # illustrates the concept.
  observePaneItems: (selector) ->
    @observePanes().flatMap (pane) ->
      pane.observeItems().filter (item) ->
        item.getTypeDescriptor?().matches(selector)
```
### Conclusion

RxJS provides a rich, seemingly mature library for working with streaming data in a compositional manner. We can utilize it in the following scenarios:
- For events, by adding `::onFoo` methods that return an observable when they aren't passed a callback.
- For changing properties and collections, by adding `::observeFoo` methods that return observables that invoke subscribers with current and future values.

It seems worth exploring as a robust solution to event handling in Atom that can slot in next to simpler approaches.

data.title: Make application:about open internally
data.body:
Similar to chrome, map the about menu internally instead of using the Mac OS X-only API that shows a simple dialog with only the version and app name.

Possible other content to put in this view:
- Packages bundled
- Packages installed

This would enable the about command to work on all platforms, refs https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2536

Other ideas welcome.

data.title: Only emit the marker-created event when the marker exists
data.body:
This caused problems in the case of find-and-replace:select-all with multiple editors into the same file. #3364
- a marker is created on the TextBuffer capturing the selection
- DisplayBuffer:create-marker is fired from the first DisplayBuffer. The marker is turned into a selection which is merged into the current selection, deleting the marker that was created.
- DisplayBuffer::handleBufferMarkerCreated is called on the second DisplayBuffer. The marker has been destroyed at this point, so it emits DisplayBuffer:create-marker with undefined. 
- ERROR

Closes #3364

data.title: "Soft wrap at preferred line length" should be based on the actual width
data.body: It should be based on the actual text width instead of just the number of letters. Non-western Unicode characters are not in the same width as ASCII characters.

data.title: Try to save Read Only files on Windows : Uncaught Error: EPERM, operation not permitted
data.body: This event should be handled with an intentional UI.

data.title: woops
Soft Tabs autodetection is broken
data.body:
Hello,
I've found that no matter what setting/file content is present, Atom will always prefer spaces over tabs if a file starts with a byte-order-mark.

This is because the "usesSoftTabs" function checks for the presence of a tab, instead of the absence of a space. The regex being used to gather lines just checks for "whitespace," meaning that usesSoftTabs is checking if non-breaking spaces, etc, of which the Byte Order Mark is one, is not a tab. 

A file full of hard tabs, with no leading spaces whatsoever, will still have Soft Tabs turned on if it starts with a BOM. I've fixed this by instead checking for leading spaces, instead of leading tabs, in usesSoftTabs.

The pull request is at https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/3369

Originally discussed at https://discuss.atom.io/t/tabs-still-dont-work-package-related/11088/4

data.title: Dont handle ctrl+click mouse events on OSX
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/3308.

Ctrl+click on OSX brings up the context menu. In that case, handling the click event deselects any selection, and that shouldn't happen.

cc @nathansobo @benogle I don't have any better ideas about fixing these kinds of issues. If you have suggestions -- let me know.

data.title: Jarring resizing with split panes
data.body:
Split workspace into 2 panes and open about 10 tabs in each one.
Click each tab one by one to change focus.

Upon clicking on about the 6th or 7th something happens that causes the left pane to jarringly resize to very wide and the right pane to very small. Then a split second later it flings back to 50/50.

I think it has something to do with the editor having to reload that buffer or create a new view.  Probably the div element that holds the width is not there causing the webkit flow to collapse. The element is added on next tick. EditorView or some such.

forum discussion here: https://discuss.atom.io/t/splits-panes-squirm-when-opening-new-tabs/11731

data.title: Better autodetection of Soft Tabs.
data.body:
Check for the presence of a space, instead of the absence of a tab.
This ensures that Soft Tabs will not be activated on a file that (for
example) starts with a BOM or something, but is otherwise full of hard
tabs.

This issue is discussed on the Atom discussion board at:
https://discuss.atom.io/t/tabs-still-dont-work-package-related

data.title: Multiple repositories inside a project
data.body:
OS : Windows
Version : Latest - Stable

Atom seems to detect and work with only one repository in a project (root project repository).
When you have multiple git repositories (into subfolders, etc), changes done into them are not visible in Atom (highlights modified lines, etc).

Original post : https://discuss.atom.io/t/multiple-git-repositories-in-a-php-composer-project/11725/3

data.title: Unable to use some git commands from atom or sub-packages.
data.body:
git-pull, merge so far don't work from within packages in atom.

To fix this I did the following (OSX):
- cd /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/MacOS/
- mv Atom Atom-bin
- vi Atom
- paste:

```
#!/bin/sh
${0}-bin
```
- save
- chmod +x Atom

When I start Atom it can now use git commands like no ones business but updating fails.

Here is the error I get when using git-pull:

```
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/libexec/git-core/git-pull: line 11: git-sh-setup: No such file or directory
```

I am using Yosemite at this point DP6. I had this issue on DP5 and PB1 as well.

Another way to fix it is to manually modify a few git-core files and hardcode a few file locations.

Please let me know if there's any more info I can provide. Thanks!

data.title: Ruby enVironment Manager's "cd" function interferes with Atom package management
data.body:
Atom 0.123.0, Ubuntu/Linux 14.04 --
[per lee-dohm's suggestion, reposted as atom/apm issue #182](http://github.com/atom/apm/issues/182), please close this #3366 if it's posted in wrong place

cmd-, to Settings, click on Packages, got pink boxes saying "Fetching updates/features failed, click to show Output."  Clicked:

/opt/atom/resources/app/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/bin/apm: line 2: __rvm_cd_functions_set: command not found

RVM defines its own bash function, 'cd', which uses/imposes its own alias(?) command '__rvm_cd_functions_set' -- I wish it didn't, but there it is.

SUGGESTION: atom should be sure to use "builtin cd" for internal cd commands... see "man bash", the SHELL BUILTIN COMMANDS section for "builtin" to guard against bad citizens like RVM's misappropriation of cd.  In practice, RVM may not be the only programming component or external package that redefines 'cd', and good practice would use "builtin" to guard against externals like this.

WORKAROUND:  If I 'unset cd' to remove RVM's function definition of 'cd', and then restart atom from that shell session (terminal), Settings|Package works again, and I can install a package.  (But now what have I lost re: RVM, if only temporarily?)
